Sina,

You may also want to look at multiagent HyperNEAT, which does essent=
ially what you are asking about.  It evolve a team that is not controlled b=
y a centralized controller yet is coordinated.  It basically does what Pete=
r described, i.e. a CPPN maps to a set of agents with their own coordinate =
frames.  You can learn about it here:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications=
/2010/dambrosio.aamas10.html

We also released a version of it that comes w=
ith its own multiagent simulator:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html#mu=
ltiagentSim

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_ch=
ervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Sina, 
> 
> You can try a coevolutionary approa=
ch in which multiple populations compete or cooperate with each other. For =
this just regular NEAT is apropriate and in my opinion it should work fine.=
 Another possibility is to use real-time NEAT like in the NERO game. You ca=
n still try HyperNEAT, but the CPPN to substrate mapping should be designed=
 such that every individual has his own coordinate frame, and if you want y=
our agents to be learning in real-time, you can also have the CPPN output y=
our learning coefficients just like the weights.  
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
> --- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, Sina Iravanian <sina_iravanian@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi =
all,
> > 
> > I want to use NEAT for learning coordination in a multi-agent=
 system.
> > But the agents in the system must be learning independently, i=
.e., they cannot communicate and a centralized controller cannot be used. 
=
> > 
> > I would be grateful if anyone could introduce some previous work, =
or publications which use NEAT (or any of its variants) in the same setting=
s. 
> > 
> > Many thanks in advance,
> > Sina
> >
>
